awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research; The Role Of Function In Traditional Weapon Design
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to understand the role that function plays in traditional weaponry design. It will investigate the evolution of Ice Age stone tool weaponry, dated to13,500 to 12,500 years, used by hunter-gatherers in the colonization of North America. The weapons, stone point tips attached to spears and called "Clovis points" by archaeologists, were flintknapped into specimens with parallel to slightly convex sides, a concave base, and flake-removal scars; termed "flutes." These flutes occur on one or both faces and on average extend from the base to about a third of the way to the tip. These points are found across North America, having spread widely and rapidly at an unprecedented rate. During this expansion over space, across time, and in different environments the size and shape of Clovis points changed significantly. Archaeologists know that cultural drift contributed to this variation, but is it possible that this single source could alone generate so much variation so quickly? Or are multiple sources, for example cultural drift + functional changes, necessary to so rapidly give rise to such variety? If functional differences are found among different forms of Clovis points, it follows that Clovis people in different times and places may have chosen specific attributes to provide them with a selective functional advantage. The project will contribute to the overall understanding of how and why weapons evolve among small, mobile, isolated groups of humans; a fundamental anthropological question of broad archaeological and ethnographic relevance, as well as to many situations in the present day. Furthermore, since the peopling of the Americas was part of the broader late Pleistocene global dispersal of human out of Africa, this project will ultimately advance the understanding of the behavioral and technological adaptations that determined how our species came to so successfully colonize the planet. 

The investigators will examine whether different sizes and shapes of Clovis points possess any functional advantages or disadvantages. Through a series of realistic hunting-related experiments in conjunction with a series of controlled engineering experiments, the researchers will determine the prey penetration-ability, aerodynamics, durability, fracture mechanics, and cutting-efficiency of replica Clovis points of varying forms.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to understand the role that function plays in traditional weapon design. Ice Age stone weaponry used by hunter-gatherers in the colonization of North America have shown an evolution in weapon design. These weapons, comprising stone tips attached to spears, were flintknapped into specimens with parallel to slightly convex sides, a concave base, and flake-removal scars called ?flutes?. A wide range of tip geometries have been discovered, but the relationship between form and function has not yet been fully characterized. This project included an interdisciplinary effort between archaeologists (Kent State University and the University of Tulsa) and engineers (Southern Methodist University) to investigate the relationship between various tip geometry metrics and tip performance, specifically the ability of the tip to penetrate a medium.

14 different tip geometries were created for use in testing; multiple samples were created for each of the 14 geometries. Fundamental tip geometry metrics including length, width, and thickness were measured at consistent intervals along the length of each point. From these fundamental metrics, additional tip geometry metrics were derived, including tip cross-sectional area (TCSA), tip cross-sectional perimeter (TCSP), lateral surface area (LSA), and volume (V). The mass of each tip was also recorded. Specimens were tested in two suites of tests: dynamic penetration testing and static penetration testing. In dynamic penetration testing, tips were hafted to shafts and fired from a bow into a clay target using a constant draw weight and distance across all tests to ensure constant kinetic energy. Velocity and penetration depth were recorded for each tip fired, which included 30 specimens from each of the 14 different tip geometries. Using this data and performing ordinary least squares (OLS) regression analyses between tip geometry metrics and penetration depth, TCSA and TCSP were shown to have a strong inverse relationship with penetration depth, with TCSP in particular acting as a robust predictor of tip penetration performance. Tips with higher TCSP values penetrated less deeply than those with lower TCSP values. The results from the dynamic penetration testing strongly support the hypothesis that tip cross-sectional geometry metrics predict tip penetration performance.

Static penetration testing comprised using a load frame to slowly (quasi-statically) embed tips into a clay sample. Throughout each test, tip displacement and applied load were recorded. Two sets of static penetration tests were conducted; the first set of tests included 10 specimens from each of the 14 different tip geometries with a maximum prescribed displacement of 25.4 mm, and the second set of tests included 4 specimens from each of the 14 different tip geometries with a maximum prescribed displacement of 152.4 mm. Load-deflection curves were created for each test and were used to calculate the energy required for each tip to reach a targeted penetration depth. The relationships between these energies and the tip geometry metrics (TCSA, TCSP, LSA, and V) were investigated using OLS regression analyses. Results showed that TCSP was the most robust single predictor of tip penetration performance, which was consistent with the results from the dynamic penetration testing. Multiple regression analyses were also conducted to investigate the use of single tip geometry metrics evaluated at multiple locations along the length of a tip and the use of multiple tip geometry metrics evaluated at a single location along the length of a tip. Results showed that using multiple predictors (either multiple tip geometry metrics or a single metric evaluated at multiple locations) was consistently more robust at predicting tip penetration performance than using a single metric at a single location.

In addition to the results discussed above, the major outcomes of this project include providing additional metric tools for making functional performance inferences about stone weapon tips and suggest that metrics beyond those traditionally considered (TCSA and TCSP) should be investigated. This project has also led to the development of interdisciplinary partnerships between partner universities that were instrumental in the success of this project and can serve to encourage further interdisciplinary research efforts within the broader research community.
